content.text: The student hangs the card on the nail through hole **A**. He checks that the card is able to swing freely and then hangs the plumbline from the nail so that it is close to, but not touching, the card. When the card and plumbline are still, he makes a small mark at the edge of the card where the plumbline crosses the edge. He removes the card and draws a line from the mark to hole **A**
He repeats the procedure using holes **B** and **C**
Fig.1.2 is a drawing of the card

If the experiment is completely accurate, the centre of mass of the card is at the position where the three lines meet. On Fig. 1.2, judge the best position for the centre of mass, marking it with a small cross. Draw a line from this position to the right-angled corner of the card and measure the distance \(a\) between the centre of mass and the right-angled corner of the card

In this experiment, it is important that the card is able to swing freely. For this reason, the plumbline should not touch the card but be a small distance from it. This could cause an inaccuracy in marking the card at the correct position. Describe how you would minimise this possible inaccuracy. You may draw a diagram
An IGCSE student is determining the position of the centre of mass of a triangular ca
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 1.1

parts.label: (a)

content.text: Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) as shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.2

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode
LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: Complete the column headings in Table 2.1

parts.label: (ii)

content.text: Calculate the temperature fall \(T_{1}\) during the first 30 s of cooling

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode
LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

parts.label: (iii)

content.text: Calculate the temperature fall \(T_{2}\) during the final 30 s of cooling

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode
LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: The beaker contains \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water. A student takes temperature readings as the water cools, as shown in Table 2.1
Plot the graph of temperature \((y\text{-axis})\) against time \((x\text{-axis})\)
State how the rate of cooling in the first 30 s differs from that in the final 30 s
Explain how the graph line shows this difference
[Total: 11]
The IGCSE class is investigating the rate of cooling of water
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 2.1
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of each lamp, using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\), and enter the results in the table
Add together the two values of \(R\) to calculate \(R_{\mathrm{S}}\), the sum of the resistances of the two lamps

content.text: A student records the potential difference \(V\) across the lamps and the current \(I\) in lamp 1. She rearranges the circuit so that the ammeter is connected in series with lamp 2 and again records the potential difference \(V\) across the lamps and the current \(I\) in lamp 2
The readings are shown in Table 3.1
Draw a circuit diagram of the rearranged circuit using conventional symbols
Use the voltmeter and ammeter readings to calculate \(R_{\mathrm{T}}\), the combined resistance of the two lamps in series
The student rearranges the circuit so that the lamps and the ammeter are in series does not change the position of the voltmeter
She records the readings on the voltmeter and the ammeter

A student suggests that the values of \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{S}}\) and \(\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{T}}\) should be equal. State whether the results support this suggestion and justify your statement by reference to the calculated values
statement
justification

State, without reference to the values of resistance that you have calculated, one piece of evidence that the student can observe during the experiment that shows that the temperature of the lamp filaments changes
[Total: 9]
The IGCSE class is measuring the currents in lamps in different circuits
The first circuit is shown in Fig. 3.1
Draw a normal to line \(\mathbf{MR}\) at \(\mathbf{N}\)

Draw a line \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long that is parallel to line \(\mathbf{MR}\) and \(12\mathrm{cm}\) below it. The ends of this line must be at the same distance from the edges of the page as the ends of line \(\mathbf{MR}\). Label this line \(\mathbf{CD}\) with \(\mathbf{C}\) directly below \(\mathbf{M}\)
Draw a line from \(\mathbf{C}\) to \(\mathbf{N}\)
Measure and record the angle of incidence \(i\) between the line \(\mathbf{CN}\) and the normal
The student places a pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) so that it stands vertically at \(\mathbf{C}\). He places another pin \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) as close as possible to the point \(\mathbf{N}\)
Draw in the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets the normal
Measure and record the angle of reflection \(r\) between the normal and line \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\mathsf{P}_{4}\)
The student views the image in the mirror of the pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) from the direction indicated

the eye in Fig. 4.1. He places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) some distance apart so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}, \mathsf{P}_{2}\) and the image of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) are shown on Fig. 4.1

Several students found that, in spite of carrying out this experiment with reasonable care, the measured value of the angle of reflection \(r\) was not exactly the same as the value obtained from theory
Suggest two possible causes of this inaccuracy
[Total: 9]
The IGCSE class is investigating reflection of light using a plane mirror
A student has set up a ray trace sheet and this is shown in Fig. 4.1. The line \(\mathbf{MR}\) shows the position of a plane mirror
P3
eye
